papers.title: Can neural networks do arithmetic? A survey on the elementary numerical skills of state-of-the-art deep learning models
papers.authors: Alberto Testolin
papers.summary: This survey critically examines the recent literature, concluding that even state-of-the-art architectures often fall short when probed with relatively simple tasks designed to test basic numerical and arithmetic knowledge.

papers.title: A Survey of Deep Learning for Mathematical Reasoning
papers.venue: Annual Meeting of the Association for Computational Linguistics
papers.authors: Pan Lu,Liang Qiu,Wenhao Yu,S. Welleck,Kai-Wei Chang
papers.summary: This survey paper reviews the key tasks, datasets, and methods at the intersection of mathematical reasoning and deep learning over the past decade, and evaluates existing benchmarks and methods and discusses future research directions in this domain.

papers.title: A Causal Framework to Quantify the Robustness of Mathematical Reasoning with Language Models
papers.venue: Annual Meeting of the Association for Computational Linguistics
papers.authors: Alessandro Stolfo,Zhijing Jin,K. Shridhar,B. Scholkopf,Mrinmaya Sachan
papers.summary: This work proposes a novel framework, which pins down the causal effect of various factors in the input, e.g., the surface form of the problem text, the operands, and math operators on the output solution, and applies this framework on a test bed of math word problems.

papers.title: Reasoning with Transformer-based Models: Deep Learning, but Shallow Reasoning
papers.venue: Conference on Automated Knowledge Base Construction
papers.authors: Chadi Helwe,C. Clavel,Fabian M. Suchanek
papers.summary: This survey paper discusses the performance of transformers on diﬀerent reasoning tasks, including mathematical reasoning, commonsense reasoning, and logical reasoning.

papers.title: Teaching Algorithmic Reasoning via In-context Learning
papers.authors: Hattie Zhou,Azade Nova,H. Larochelle,Aaron C. Courville,Behnam Neyshabur,Hanie Sedghi
papers.summary: This work shows that it is possible to teach algorithmic reasoning to LLMs via in-context learning, which it is referred to as algorithmic prompting, and evaluates the approach on a variety of arithmetic and quantitative reasoning tasks, and demonstrates significant boosts in performance.

papers.title: Estimating Numbers without Regression
papers.authors: Avijit Thawani,Jay Pujara,Ashwin Kalyan
papers.summary: A carefully designed tokenization scheme is both the simplest to implement and sufficient, with similar performance to the state-of-the-art approach that requires making significant architectural changes, in the context of masked number prediction.

papers.title: Measurement Extraction with Natural Language Processing: A Review
papers.venue: Conference on Empirical Methods in Natural Language Processing
papers.authors: Jan Göpfert,Patrick Kuckertz,J. Weinand,Leander Kotzur,D. Stolten
papers.summary: In this review, an overview of prior work on measurement extraction is presented and different approaches to measurement extraction are described and the challenges posed by this task are outlined.

papers.title: Reasoning with Language Model Prompting: A Survey
papers.venue: Annual Meeting of the Association for Computational Linguistics
papers.authors: Shuofei Qiao,Yixin Ou,Ningyu Zhang,Xiang Chen,Yunzhi Yao,Shumin Deng,Chuanqi Tan,Fei Huang,Huajun Chen
papers.summary: This paper provides a comprehensive survey of cutting-edge research on reasoning with language model prompting with comparisons and summaries and provides systematic resources to help beginners.

papers.title: How well do Large Language Models perform in Arithmetic tasks?
papers.authors: Zheng Yuan,Hongyi Yuan,Chuanqi Tan,Wei Wang,Songfang Huang
papers.summary: This work proposes an arithmetic dataset MATH 401 to test the latest large language models including GPT-4, ChatG PT, InstrctGPT, Galactica, and LLaMA with various arithmetic expressions and provides a detailed analysis of the ability of largelanguage models.

papers.title: Goat: Fine-tuned LLaMA Outperforms GPT-4 on Arithmetic Tasks
papers.authors: Tiedong Liu,K. H. Low
papers.summary: Goat, a fine-tuned LLaMA model that significantly outperforms GPT-4 on a range of arithmetic tasks, is introduced and an approach that classifies tasks based on their learnability, and subsequently decomposes unlearnable tasks into a series of learnable tasks by leveraging basic arithmetic principles is proposed.

papers.title: Towards Reasoning in Large Language Models: A Survey
papers.venue: Annual Meeting of the Association for Computational Linguistics
papers.authors: Jie Huang,K. Chang
papers.summary: A comprehensive overview of the current state of knowledge on reasoning in large language models, including techniques for improving and eliciting reasoning in these models, methods and benchmarks for evaluating reasoning abilities, findings and implications of previous research in this field, and suggestions on future directions are provided.

papers.title: Controlling Neural Network Smoothness for Neural Algorithmic Reasoning
papers.authors: David A. Klindt
papers.summary: A tight linkage between the scaling of a network weights’ standard deviation and its effective length scale on a sinusoidal regression problem is demonstrated, suggesting simple modifications to control the length scale of the function learned by a neural network and, thus, its smoothness.

papers.title: QA Dataset Explosion: A Taxonomy of NLP Resources for Question Answering and Reading Comprehension
papers.authors: Anna Rogers,Matt Gardner,Isabelle Augenstein
papers.summary: This study is the largest survey of the deep learning models in NLP field to date, providing an overview of the various formats and domains of the current resources, and highlighting the current lacunae for future work.

papers.title: Benchmarks for Automated Commonsense Reasoning: A Survey
papers.authors: E. Davis
papers.summary: A number of recommendations for future development of commonsense AI benchmarks are made, including that the creators of benchmarks invest the work needed to ensure that benchmark examples are consistently high quality.

papers.title: Complex QA and language models hybrid architectures, Survey
papers.authors: Xavier Daull,P. Bellot,Emmanuel Bruno,Vincent Martin,Elisabeth Murisasco
papers.summary: This paper reviews the state-of-the-art of language models architectures and strategies for "complex"question-answering (QA, C QA, CPS) with a focus on hybridization, and discusses some challenges associated with complex QA.

papers.title: CREATOR: Tool Creation for Disentangling Abstract and Concrete Reasoning of Large Language Models
papers.authors: Cheng Qian,Chi Han,Y. Fung,Yujia Qin,Zhiyuan Liu,Heng Ji
papers.summary: The proposed CREATOR, a novel framework that enables LLMs to create their own tools using documentation and code realization, disentangles abstract tool creation and concrete decision execution, resulting in improved performance.

papers.title: Evaluating and Improving Tool-Augmented Computation-Intensive Math Reasoning
papers.authors: Beichen Zhang,Kun Zhou,Xilin Wei,Wayne Xin Zhao,Jing Sha,Shijin Wang,Ji-rong Wen
papers.summary: Experimental results on CARP and six other datasets show that the proposed DELI mostly outperforms competitive baselines, and can further boost the performance of existing CoT methods.

papers.title: Exploring Equation as a Better Intermediate Meaning Representation for Numerical Reasoning
papers.authors: Dingzirui Wang,Longxu Dou,Wenbin Zhang,Junyu Zeng,Wanxiang Che
papers.summary: This paper presents a method called Boosting Numerical Reason\textbfing by Decomposing the Generation of Equations (Bridge), which can improve the accuracy of LLMs in generating equations as IMRs by reducing the tendency of generating constant expressions and programs.

papers.title: Design of Chain-of-Thought in Math Problem Solving
papers.authors: Zhanming Jie,Trung Quoc Luong,Xinbo Zhang,Xiaoran Jin,Hang Li
papers.summary: Through extensive experiments on GSM8K, MATHQA, and SVAMP, it is found that program CoTs often have superior effectiveness in math problem solving and Python is a better choice of language than Wolfram for program CoT.

papers.title: Neural Comprehension: Language Models with Compiled Neural Networks
papers.authors: Yixuan Weng,Minjun Zhu,Fei Xia,Bin Li,Shizhu He,Kang Liu,Jun Zhao
papers.summary: The method, which call "Neural Comprehension", helps language models achieve absolute accuracy in symbolic operations, thereby enhancing their ability for rule reasoning, symbolic reasoning, and arithmetic reasoning.

papers.title: PAL: Program-aided Language Models
papers.authors: Luyu Gao,Aman Madaan,Shuyan Zhou,Uri Alon,Pengfei Liu,Yiming Yang,Jamie Callan,Graham Neubig
papers.summary: This paper presents Program-Aided Language models (PAL): a novel approach that uses the LLM to read natural language problems and generate programs as the intermediate reasoning steps, but offloads the solution step to a runtime such as a Python interpreter.

papers.title: GPT Can Solve Mathematical Problems Without a Calculator
papers.authors: Z. Yang,Ming Ding,Qingsong Lv,Zhihuan Jiang,Zehai He,Yuyi Guo,Jinfeng Bai,Jie Tang
papers.summary: The MathGLM, fine-tuned from GLM-10B on a dataset with additional multi-step arithmetic operations and math problems described in text, achieves similar performance to GPT-4 on a 5,000-samples Chinese math problem test set.

papers.title: KitchenScale: Learning to predict ingredient quantities from recipe contexts
papers.authors: Donghee Choi,Mogan Gim,Samy Badreddine,Hajung Kim,Donghyeon Park,Jaewoo Kang
papers.summary: This work introduces KitchenScale, a fine-tuned Pre- trained Pre-trained Language Model (PLM) that predicts a target ingredient's quantity and measurement unit given its recipe context and adopted the Discrete Latent Exponent method to cope with high variance of numerical scales in recipe corpora.

papers.title: Relational World Knowledge Representation in Contextual Language Models: A Review
papers.venue: Conference on Empirical Methods in Natural Language Processing
papers.authors: Tara Safavi,Danai Koutra
papers.summary: This work proposes to organize knowledge representation strategies in LMs by the level of KB supervision provided, from no KB supervision at all to entity- and relation-level supervision, and provides a high-level, extensible taxonomy for knowledge representation in L Ms.

papers.title: STOAT: Structured Data to Analytical Text With Controls
papers.authors: Deepanway Ghosal,Preksha Nema,A. Raghuveer
papers.summary: STOAT model is proposed, which is table and reasoning aware, with vector-quantization to infuse the given reasoning categories in the output and generates 15.3% more faithful and analytical descriptions as compared to the baseline models in human evaluation.

papers.title: A Survey of Chain of Thought Reasoning: Advances, Frontiers and Future
papers.authors: Zheng Chu,Jingchang Chen,Qianglong Chen,Weijiang Yu,Tao He,Haotian Wang,Weihua Peng,Ming Liu,Bing Qin,Ting Liu
papers.summary: A thorough survey of the current research according to the taxonomies of methods within the domain of chain-of-thought reasoning, and describes XoT with frontier applications, covering planning, tool use, and distillation.

papers.title: Language Model Behavior: A Comprehensive Survey
papers.authors: Tyler A. Chang,B. Bergen
papers.summary: Over 250 recent studies of English language model behavior before task-specific fine-tuning are discussed, synthesizing recent results to highlight what is currently known about large language model capabilities, thus providing a resource for applied work and for research in adjacent fields that use language models.

papers.title: Teaching Arithmetic to Small Transformers
papers.authors: Nayoung Lee,Kartik K. Sreenivasan,Jason D. Lee,Kangwook Lee,Dimitris Papailiopoulos
papers.summary: This study investigates how small transformers, trained from random initialization, can efficiently learn arithmetic operations such as addition, multiplication, and elementary functions like square root, using the next-token prediction objective.

papers.title: JiuZhang 2.0: A Unified Chinese Pre-trained Language Model for Multi-task Mathematical Problem Solving
papers.authors: Wayne Xin Zhao,Kun Zhou,Beichen Zhang,Zheng Gong,Zhipeng Chen,Yuanhang Zhou,Ji-rong Wen,Jing Sha,Shijin Wang,Cong Liu,Guoping Hu
papers.summary: The idea is to maintain a moderate-sized model and employ the cross-task knowledge sharing to improve the model capacity in a multi-task setting, and construct a Mixture-of-Experts (MoE) architecture for modeling mathematical text, to capture the common mathematical knowledge across tasks.

papers.title: SciBench: Evaluating College-Level Scientific Problem-Solving Abilities of Large Language Models
papers.authors: Xiaoxuan Wang,Ziniu Hu,Pan Lu,Yanqiao Zhu,Jieyu Zhang,Satyen Subramaniam,Arjun R. Loomba,Shichang Zhang,Yizhou Sun,Wei Wang

papers.title: Learning Multi-step Reasoning from Arithmetic Task
papers.authors: Tianduo Wang,Wei Lu
papers.summary: This work investigates how to incorporate relatively small LMs with the capabilities of multi-step reasoning by continually pre-training LMs on a synthetic dataset M S AT, which stands for M ulti- s tep A rithmetic T ask.

papers.title: Dynamic Prompt Learning via Policy Gradient for Semi-structured Mathematical Reasoning
papers.authors: Pan Lu,Liang Qiu,Kai-Wei Chang,Y. Wu,Song-Chun Zhu,Tanmay Rajpurohit,Peter Clark,A. Kalyan
papers.summary: A novel approach is proposed, PromptPG, which utilizes policy gradient to learn to select in-context examples from a small amount of training data and then constructs the corresponding prompt for the test example, which verifies its effectiveness in selecting in- context examples.

papers.title: Mastering Symbolic Operations: Augmenting Language Models with Compiled Neural Networks
papers.authors: Yixuan Weng,Minjun Zhu,Fei Xia,Bin Li,Shizhu He,Kang Liu,Jun Zhao
papers.summary: By incorporating CoNN modules into the LM, the framework effectively tackles rule-intensive challenges and achieves flawless execution on symbolic operations tasks, highlighting the potential of the method in enabling LMs to possess true symbolic comprehension capabilities.

papers.title: Chameleon: Plug-and-Play Compositional Reasoning with Large Language Models
papers.authors: Pan Lu,Baolin Peng,Hao Cheng,Michel Galley,Kai-Wei Chang,Y. Wu,Song-Chun Zhu,Jianfeng Gao
papers.summary: This paper presents Chameleon, an AI system that mitigates LLM limitations by augmenting LLMs with plug-and-play modules for compositional reasoning, and shows that the GPT-4-powered planner exhibits more consistent and rational tool selection via inferring potential constraints from instructions, compared to a ChatGPT- powered planner.

papers.title: Progressive-Hint Prompting Improves Reasoning in Large Language Models
papers.authors: Chuanyang Zheng,Zhengying Liu,Enze Xie,Zhenguo Li,Yu Li
papers.summary: This paper proposes a new prompting method, named Progressive-Hint Prompting (PHP), that enables automatic multiple interactions between users and LLMs by using previously generated answers as hints to progressively guide toward the correct answers.

papers.title: MLCopilot: Unleashing the Power of Large Language Models in Solving Machine Learning Tasks
papers.authors: Lei Zhang,Yuge Zhang,Kan Ren,Dongsheng Li,Yuqing Yang
papers.summary: This paper aims to bridge the gap between machine intelligence and human knowledge by introducing a novel framework MLCopilot, which leverages the state-of-the-art LLMs to develop ML solutions for novel tasks, and showcases the possibility of extending the capability of LLM to comprehend structured inputs and perform thorough reasoning for solving novel ML tasks.

papers.title: Plan-and-Solve Prompting: Improving Zero-Shot Chain-of-Thought Reasoning by Large Language Models
papers.venue: Annual Meeting of the Association for Computational Linguistics
papers.authors: Lei Wang,Wanyu Xu,Yihuai Lan,Zhiqiang Hu,Yunshi Lan,R. Lee,Ee-Peng Lim
papers.summary: The experimental results over GPT-3 show that the proposed zero-shot prompting consistently outperforms Zero- shot-CoT across all datasets by a large margin, is comparable to or exceeds Zero-shot-Program-of-Thought Prompting, and has comparable performance with 8-shot CoT prompting on the math reasoning problem.

papers.title: Comprehensive Solution Program Centric Pretraining for Table-and-Text Hybrid Numerical Reasoning
papers.authors: Qianying Liu,Dongsheng Yang,Wenjie Zhong,Fei Cheng,S. Kurohashi
papers.summary: Three pretraining tasks that operate at both the whole program and sub-program level are proposed: Variable Integrity Ranking, which guides the model to focus on useful variables; Variable Operator Prediction, which decomposes the supervision into fine-grained single operator prediction; and Variable Keyphrase Masking, which encourages the modelto identify key evidence that sub- programs are derived from.

papers.title: TheoremQA: A Theorem-driven Question Answering dataset
papers.authors: Wenhu Chen,Ming Yin,Max Ku,Yixin Wan,Xueguang Ma,Jianyu Xu,Tony Xia,Xinyi Wang,Pan Lu
papers.summary: This paper introduces TheoremQA, the first theorem-driven question-answering dataset designed to evaluate AI models' capabilities to apply theorems to solve challenging science problems and finds that GPT-4's capabilities to solve these problems are unparalleled, achieving an accuracy of 51% with Program-of-Thoughts Prompting.

papers.title: An Empirical Study on Challenging Math Problem Solving with GPT-4
papers.authors: Yiran Wu,Feiran Jia,Shaokun Zhang,Han-Tai Li,Erkang Zhu,Yue Wang,Y. Lee,Richard Peng,Qingyun Wu,Chi Wang
papers.summary: This work explores the frontier of using GPT-4 for solving more complex and challenging math problems, and considers MathChat, a conversational problem-solving framework newly proposed in this work.

papers.title: Learning Multi-Step Reasoning by Solving Arithmetic Tasks
papers.venue: Annual Meeting of the Association for Computational Linguistics
papers.authors: Tianduo Wang,Wei Lu
papers.summary: This work investigates how to incorporate relatively small LMs with the capabilities of multi-step reasoning by continually pre-training LMs on a synthetic dataset MsAT which is composed of Multi-step Arithmetic Tasks.

papers.title: WizardMath: Empowering Mathematical Reasoning for Large Language Models via Reinforced Evol-Instruct
papers.authors: Haipeng Luo,Qingfeng Sun,Can Xu,Pu Zhao,Jian-Guang Lou,Chongyang Tao,Xiubo Geng,Qingwei Lin,Shifeng Chen,Dongmei Zhang
papers.summary: WizardMath is presented, which enhances the mathematical reasoning abilities of Llama-2, by applying the proposed Reinforcement Learning from Evol-Instruct Feedback (RLEIF) method to the domain of math.

papers.title: When Do Program-of-Thoughts Work for Reasoning?
papers.authors: Zhen Bi,Ningyu Zhang,Yinuo Jiang,Shumin Deng,Guozhou Zheng,Huajun Chen
papers.summary: This work proposes complexity-impacted reasoning score (CIRS), which combines structural and logical attributes, to measure the correlation between code and reasoning abilities, and designs an auto-synthesizing and stratifying algorithm that applies to instruction generation for mathematical reasoning and code data filtering for code generation tasks.

papers.title: MAmmoTH: Building Math Generalist Models through Hybrid Instruction Tuning
papers.authors: Xiang Yue,Xingwei Qu,Ge Zhang,Yao Fu,Wenhao Huang,Huan Sun,Yu Su,Wenhu Chen
papers.summary: The MAmmoTH series substantially outperform existing open-source models on nine mathematical reasoning datasets across all scales with an average accuracy gain between 16% and 32%, and underscores the importance of diverse problem coverage and the use of hybrid rationales in developing superior math generalist models.

papers.title: ToRA: A Tool-Integrated Reasoning Agent for Mathematical Problem Solving
papers.authors: Zhibin Gou,Zhihong Shao,Yeyun Gong,Yelong Shen,Yujiu Yang,Minlie Huang,Nan Duan,Weizhu Chen
papers.summary: This paper proposes ToRA a series of Tool-integrated Reasoning Agents designed to solve challenging mathematical problems by seamlessly integrating natural language reasoning with the utilization of external tools, thereby amalgamating the analytical prowess of language and the computational efficiency of tools.

papers.title: Adaptive-Solver Framework for Dynamic Strategy Selection in Large Language Model Reasoning
papers.authors: Jianpeng Zhou,Wanjun Zhong,Yanlin Wang,Jiahai Wang
papers.summary: Experimental results from complex reasoning tasks reveal that the prompting method adaptation and decomposition granularity adaptation enhance performance across all tasks, and the model adaptation approach significantly reduces API costs while maintaining superior performance.

papers.title: MathCoder: Seamless Code Integration in LLMs for Enhanced Mathematical Reasoning
papers.authors: Ke Wang,Houxing Ren,Aojun Zhou,Zimu Lu,Sichun Luo,Weikang Shi,Renrui Zhang,Linqi Song,Mingjie Zhan,Hongsheng Li
papers.summary: This paper proposes a method to fine-tune open-source language models, enabling them to use code for modeling and deriving math equations and, consequently, enhancing their mathematical reasoning abilities, and yields the MathCoder models, a family of models capable of generating code-based solutions for solving challenging math problems.

papers.title: Toolink: Linking Toolkit Creation and Using through Chain-of-Solving on Open-Source Model
papers.authors: Cheng Qian,Chenyan Xiong,Zhenghao Liu,Zhiyuan Liu
papers.summary: This paper introduces Toolink, a comprehensive framework that performs task-solving by first creating a toolkit and then integrating the planning and calling of tools through a chain-of-s solving (CoS) approach, and results in LLaMA-CoS, a powerful open-source model with advanced tool-planning and tool-calling capabilities.

papers.title: Logical Tasks for Measuring Extrapolation and Rule Comprehension
papers.authors: Ippei Fujisawa,R. Kanai
papers.summary: This work defines and characterize logical tasks and discusses system requirements for their solution, and discusses the relevance of logical tasks to concepts such as extrapolation, explainability, and inductive bias.

papers.title: Auto-Regressive Next-Token Predictors are Universal Learners
papers.authors: Eran Malach
papers.summary: This work presents a theoretical framework for studying auto-regressive next-token predictors, and introduces a new complexity measure -- length complexity -- which measures the number of intermediate tokens in a CoT sequence required to approximate some target function, and examines the interplay between length complexity and other notions of complexity.

papers.title: Injecting the BM25 Score as Text Improves BERT-Based Re-rankers
papers.authors: Arian Askari,Amin Abolghasemi,G. Pasi,Wessel Kraaij,S. Verberne

papers.title: Chain of Thought Prompting Elicits Reasoning in Large Language Models
papers.authors: Jason Wei,Xuezhi Wang,Dale Schuurmans,Maarten Bosma,E. Chi,F. Xia,Quoc Le,Denny Zhou
papers.summary: Experiments on three large language models show that chain of thought prompting improves performance on a range of arithmetic, commonsense, and symbolic reasoning tasks.

papers.title: Teaching Autoregressive Language Models Complex Tasks By Demonstration
papers.authors: Gabriel Recchia
papers.summary: The results suggest that fine-tuning autoregressive language models on small sets of well-crafted demonstrations may be a useful paradigm for enabling individuals without training in machine learning to coax such models to perform some kinds of complex multi-step tasks.

papers.title: LM-Infinite: Simple On-the-Fly Length Generalization for Large Language Models
papers.authors: Chi Han,Qifan Wang,Wenhan Xiong,Yu Chen,Heng Ji,Sinong Wang
papers.summary: LM-Infinite is computationally efficient with $O(n)$ time and space, and demonstrates consistent text generation fluency and quality to as long as 128k tokens on ArXiv and OpenWebText2 datasets, with 2.72x decoding speedup.

papers.title: Impact of Pretraining Term Frequencies on Few-Shot Numerical Reasoning
papers.venue: Conference on Empirical Methods in Natural Language Processing
papers.authors: Yasaman Razeghi,IV RobertL.Logan,Matt Gardner,Sameer Singh

papers.title: A Simple, Yet Effective Approach to Finding Biases in Code Generation
papers.venue: Annual Meeting of the Association for Computational Linguistics
papers.authors: Spyridon Mouselinos,Mateusz Malinowski,H. Michalewski
papers.summary: This work introduces an automated intervention mechanism reminiscent of adversarial testing that exposes undesired biases through the failure modes of the models under test, and demonstrates how the framework can be used as a data transformation technique during fine-tuning, acting as a mitigation strategy for these biases.

papers.title: Judicial knowledge-enhanced magnitude-aware reasoning for numerical legal judgment prediction
papers.authors: Sheng Bi,Zhiyao Zhou,Lu Pan,G. Qi

papers.title: DyRRen: A Dynamic Retriever-Reranker-Generator Model for Numerical Reasoning over Tabular and Textual Data
papers.authors: X. Li,Yin Zhu,Sichen Liu,Jiangzhou Ju,Yuzhong Qu,Gong Cheng
papers.summary: DyRRen is proposed, an extended retriever-reranker-generator framework where each generation step is enhanced by a dynamic reranking of retrieved sentences that outperforms existing baselines on the FinQA dataset.

papers.title: Numeric Magnitude Comparison Effects in Large Language Models
papers.venue: Annual Meeting of the Association for Computational Linguistics
papers.authors: Raj Sanjay Shah,Vijay Marupudi,Reba Koenen,Khushi Bhardwaj,S. Varma

papers.title: Commonsense Reasoning with Implicit Knowledge in Natural Language
papers.venue: Conference on Automated Knowledge Base Construction
papers.authors: Pratyay Banerjee,Swaroop Mishra
papers.summary: This work takes a middle ground where it uses smaller language models together with a relatively smaller but targeted natural language text corpora to develop unstructured commonsense knowledge sources and explores three strategies for knowledge incorporation.

papers.title: Exploring the Learning Mechanisms of Neural Division Modules
papers.authors: Bhumika Mistry,K. Farrahi,Jonathon S. Hare
papers.summary: It is shown that robustly learning division in a systematic manner remains a challenge even at the simplest level of dividing two numbers, and a novel approach to division is proposed which is called the Neural Reciprocal Unit (NRU) and the Neural Multiplicative Reciproc Unit (NMRU).

papers.title: A Primer for Neural Arithmetic Logic Modules
papers.authors: Bhumika Mistry,K. Farrahi,Jonathon S. Hare
papers.summary: Focusing on the shortcomings of the NALU, an in-depth analysis is provided to reason about design choices of recent modules, and a benchmark is created which compares all existing arithmetic NALMs.

papers.title: Learning Division with Neural Arithmetic Logic Modules
papers.authors: Bhumika Mistry,K. Farrahi,Jonathon S. Hare
papers.summary: It is shown that robustly learning division in a systematic manner remains a challenge even at the simplest level of dividing two numbers, and two novel approaches for division are proposed, one of which is the Neural Reciprocal Unit and the NMRU.

papers.title: Knowledge Infused Decoding
papers.authors: Ruibo Liu,Guoqing Zheng,Shashank Gupta,Radhika Gaonkar,Chongyang Gao,Soroush Vosoughi,Milad Shokouhi,A. Awadallah
papers.summary: Knowledge Infused Decoding (KID) -- a novel decoding algorithm for generative LMs, which dynamically infuses external knowledge into each step of the LM decoding, which maintains a local knowledge memory based on the current context, interacting with a dynamically created external knowledge trie, and continuously update the local memory as a knowledge-aware constraint to guide decoding via reinforcement learning.

papers.title: Dissociating language and thought in large language models: a cognitive perspective
papers.authors: Kyle Mahowald,Anna A. Ivanova,I. Blank,N. Kanwisher,J. Tenenbaum,Evelina Fedorenko

papers.title: 20Q: Overlap-Free World Knowledge Benchmark for Language Models
papers.authors: Maxime De Bruyn,Ehsan Lotfi,Jeska Buhmann,Walter Daelemans
papers.summary: 20Q is introduced, a novel benchmark using the Twenty Questions game to evaluate world knowledge and common sense of language models and shows that in-context learning is inefficient for evaluating language models’ world knowledge — fine-tuning is necessary to show their true capabilities.

papers.title: Toward Building a Language Model for Understanding Temporal Commonsense
papers.authors: Mayuko Kimura,L. Pereira,Ichiro Kobayashi
papers.summary: This paper focuses on the development of language models for temporal commonsense inference over several pre-trained language models, and relies on multi-step fine-tuning using multiple corpora, and masked language modeling to predict masked temporal indicators that are crucial for temporal Commonsense reasoning.

papers.title: Good Night at 4 pm?! Time Expressions in Different Cultures
papers.authors: V. Shwartz
papers.summary: 3 language-agnostic methods are proposed for mapping from expressions such as “morning” in English or “Manhã’ in Portuguese to specific hours in the day and one achieves promising results on gold standard annotations that is collected for a small number of languages.

papers.title: Identify, Align, and Integrate: Matching Knowledge Graphs to Commonsense Reasoning Tasks
papers.venue: Conference of the European Chapter of the Association for Computational Linguistics
papers.authors: Lisa Bauer
papers.summary: This work presents an approach to assess how well a candidate KG can correctly identify and accurately fill in gaps of reasoning for a task, which is called KG-to-task match and demonstrates that ATOMIC, an event-inference focused KG, is the best match for SIQA and MCScript2.0, and that the taxonomic ConceptNet and WikiHow-based KGs are the bestmatch for PIQA across all 3 analysis phases.

papers.title: COM2SENSE: A Commonsense Reasoning Benchmark with Complementary Sentences
papers.authors: Shikhar Singh,Nuan Wen,Yu Hou,Pegah Alipoormolabashi,Te-Lin Wu,Xuezhe Ma,Nanyun Peng
papers.summary: This work introduces a new commonsense reasoning benchmark dataset comprising natural language true/false statements, with each sample paired with its complementary counterpart, resulting in 4k sentence pairs, and proposes a pairwise accuracy metric to reliably measure an agent's ability to perform Commonsense reasoning over a given situation.

papers.title: Commonsense Knowledge Reasoning and Generation with Pre-trained Language Models: A Survey
papers.authors: Prajjwal Bhargava,Vincent Ng
papers.summary: A survey of commonsense knowledge acquisition and reasoning tasks, the strengths and weaknesses of state-of-the-art pre-trained models for commonsense reasoning and generation as revealed by these tasks, and reflects on future research directions are presented.

papers.title: “John is 50 years old, can his son be 65?” Evaluating NLP Models’ Understanding of Feasibility
papers.venue: Conference of the European Chapter of the Association for Computational Linguistics
papers.authors: Himanshu Gupta,Neeraj Varshney,Swaroop Mishra,Kuntal Kumar Pal,Saurabh Arjun Sawant,Kevin Scaria,Siddharth Goyal,Chitta Baral
papers.summary: This work introduces FeasibilityQA, a question-answering dataset involving binary classification (BCQ) and multi-choice multi-correct questions (MCQ) that test understanding of feasibility, and shows that even state-of-the-art models such as GPT-3, G PT-2, and T5 struggle to answer the feasibility questions correctly.

papers.title: Test of Time: Instilling Video-Language Models with a Sense of Time
papers.authors: Piyush Bagad,Makarand Tapaswi,Cees G. M. Snoek
papers.summary: This work proposes a temporal adaptation recipe on top of one video-language model, VideoCLIp, based on post-pretraining on a small amount of video-text data and conducts a zero-shot evaluation of the adapted models on six datasets for three downstream tasks which require varying degrees of time awareness.

papers.title: FERMAT: An Alternative to Accuracy for Numerical Reasoning
papers.venue: Annual Meeting of the Association for Computational Linguistics
papers.authors: Jasivan Sivakumar,N. Moosavi
papers.summary: This work introduces a multi-view evaluation set for numerical reasoning in English, called FERMAT, which evaluates models on various key numerical reasoning aspects such as number understanding, mathematical operations, and training dependency.

papers.title: SituatedGen: Incorporating Geographical and Temporal Contexts into Generative Commonsense Reasoning
papers.authors: Yunxiang Zhang,Xiaojun Wan
papers.summary: This work introduces a corresponding English dataset consisting of 8,268 contrastive sentence pairs, which are built upon several existing commonsense reasoning benchmarks with minimal manual labor and formalizes this challenging task as SituatedGen.

papers.title: An Overview Of Temporal Commonsense Reasoning and Acquisition
papers.authors: Georg Wenzel,A. Jatowt
papers.summary: The need for careful interpretation of research is emphasized to guard against overpromising evaluation results in light of the shallow reasoning present in transformers, and the need for appropriately preparing datasets and suitable evaluation metrics is emphasized.

papers.title: Self-Attention Networks Can Process Bounded Hierarchical Languages
papers.venue: Annual Meeting of the Association for Computational Linguistics
papers.authors: Shunyu Yao,Binghui Peng,C. Papadimitriou,Karthik Narasimhan
papers.summary: It is proved that self-attention networks can process Dyck-(k, D), the subset of Dyck-k with depth bounded by D, which arguably better captures the bounded hierarchical structure of natural language.

papers.title: Length Generalization in Arithmetic Transformers
papers.authors: Samy Jelassi,Stéphane d'Ascoli,Carles Domingo-Enrich,Yuhuai Wu,Yuan-Fang Li,Franccois Charton
papers.summary: It is shown that priming allows models trained on $5-digit $\times$ $3-digit multiplications to generalize to $35\times 3$ examples, and that the priming sample size scales as the logarithm of the training set size.

papers.title: Functional Interpolation for Relative Positions Improves Long Context Transformers
papers.authors: Shanda Li,Chong You,Guru Guruganesh,J. Ainslie,Santiago Ontanon,M. Zaheer,Sumit K. Sanghai,Yiming Yang,Sanjiv Kumar,Srinadh Bhojanapalli
papers.summary: It is theoretically prove that this can represent some of the popular relative position encodings, such as T5's RPE, Alibi, and Kerple, and empirically show that FIRE models have better generalization to longer contexts on both zero-shot language modeling and long text benchmarks.

papers.title: NAPG: Non-Autoregressive Program Generation for Hybrid Tabular-Textual Question Answering
papers.venue: Natural Language Processing and Chinese Computing
papers.authors: Tengxun Zhang,Hongfei Xu,Josef van Genabith,Deyi Xiong,Hongying Zan
papers.summary: This paper proposes a non-autoregressive program generation framework, which independently generates complete program tuples containing both operators and operands, which can significantly boost the speed of program generation while addressing the error accumulation issue.

papers.title: FORTAP: Using Formulas for Numerical-Reasoning-Aware Table Pretraining
papers.venue: Annual Meeting of the Association for Computational Linguistics
papers.authors: Zhoujun Cheng,Haoyu Dong,Fan Cheng,Ran Jia,Pengfei Wu,Shi Han,Dongmei Zhang
papers.summary: This paper proposes FORTAP, the first exploration to leverage spreadsheet formulas for table pretraining with tree attention, and proposes two novel self-supervised pretraining objectives derived from formulas, numerical reference prediction (NRP) and numerical calculation prediction (NCP).

papers.title: Unsupervised Numerical Reasoning to Extract Phenotypes from Clinical Text by Leveraging External Knowledge
papers.authors: Ashwani Tanwar,Jingqing Zhang,Julia Ive,Vibhor Gupta,Yike Guo
papers.summary: A novel unsupervised methodology leveraging external knowledge and contextualized word embeddings from ClinicalBERT for numerical reasoning in a variety of phenotypic contexts is presented.

papers.title: Phenotyping in clinical text with unsupervised numerical reasoning for patient stratification
papers.authors: Ashwani Tanwar,Jingqing Zhang,Julia Ive,Vibhor Gupta,Yike Guo
papers.summary: This article proposes a novel unsupervised method that leverages external clinical knowledge and contextualized word embeddings by ClinicalBERT for numerical reasoning in different phenotypic contexts and finds that these phenotypes from clinical text can be used to impute the missing values in structured data, which enrich and improve data quality.

papers.title: Towards Understanding Chain-of-Thought Prompting: An Empirical Study of What Matters
papers.venue: Annual Meeting of the Association for Computational Linguistics
papers.authors: Boshi Wang,Sewon Min,Xiang Deng,Jiaming Shen,You Wu,Luke Zettlemoyer,Huan Sun
papers.summary: It is shown that CoT reasoning is possible even with invalid demonstrations - prompting with invalid reasoning steps can achieve over 80-90% of the performance obtained using CoT under various metrics, while still generating coherent lines of reasoning during inference.

papers.title: Koala: An Index for Quantifying Overlaps with Pre-training Corpora
papers.authors: Thuy-Trang Vu,Xuanli He,Gholamreza Haffari,Ehsan Shareghi
papers.summary: Koala, a searchable index over large pre-training corpora using compressed suffix arrays with highly efficient compression rate and search support, is launched, providing a framework to do forensic analysis on the current and future benchmarks as well as to assess the degree of memorization in the output from the LLMs.

papers.title: SEER: A Knapsack approach to Exemplar Selection for In-Context HybridQA
papers.authors: Jonathan Tonglet,Manon Reusens,Philipp Borchert,Bart Baesens
papers.summary: This work presents Selection of ExEmplars for hybrid Reasoning (SEER), a novel method for selecting a set of exemplars that is both representative and diverse and formulates exemplar selection as a Knapsack Integer Linear Program.

papers.title: A Survey on Medical Document Summarization
papers.authors: Raghav Jain,Anubhav Jangra,S. Saha,A. Jatowt
papers.summary: This paper gives a comprehensive survey of the current techniques and trends in medical summarization.

papers.title: Learning Non-linguistic Skills without Sacrificing Linguistic Proficiency
papers.venue: Annual Meeting of the Association for Computational Linguistics
papers.authors: Mandar Sharma,N. Muralidhar,Naren Ramakrishnan

papers.title: ML-LJP: Multi-Law Aware Legal Judgment Prediction
papers.venue: Annual International ACM SIGIR Conference on Research and Development in Information Retrieval
papers.authors: Yifei Liu,Yiquan Wu,Yating Zhang,Changlong Sun,Weiming Lu,Fei Wu,Kun Kuang
papers.summary: Following the actual legal process, the law article prediction is expanded as a multi-label classification task that includes both the charge-related law articles and term-relatedlaw articles and a novel multi-law aware LJP (ML-LJP) method is proposed to improve the performance of LJP.

papers.title: PACIFIC: Towards Proactive Conversational Question Answering over Tabular and Textual Data in Finance
papers.venue: Conference on Empirical Methods in Natural Language Processing
papers.authors: Yang Deng,Wenqiang Lei,Wenxuan Zhang,W. Lam,Tat-Seng Chua
papers.summary: A novel method is proposed, namely UniPCQA, to adapt a hybrid format of input and output content in PCQA into the Seq2Seq problem, including the reformulation of the numerical reasoning process as code generation.

papers.title: Understanding Arithmetic Reasoning in Language Models using Causal Mediation Analysis
papers.authors: Alessandro Stolfo,Yonatan Belinkov,Mrinmaya Sachan
papers.summary: A mechanistic interpretation of LLMs for arithmetic-based questions using a causal mediation analysis framework, which identifies the subset of parameters responsible for specific predictions and investigates the role of the attention mechanism.

papers.title: Doc2SoarGraph: Discrete Reasoning over Visually-Rich Table-Text Documents with Semantic-Oriented Hierarchical Graphs
papers.authors: Fengbin Zhu,Chao Wang,Fuli Feng,Zifeng Ren,Moxin Li,Tat-Seng Chua
papers.summary: This work proposes a novel Doc2SoarGraph framework with enhanced discrete reasoning capability by harnessing the differences and correlations among different elements of the given question and document with Semantic-oriented hierarchical Graph structures.

papers.title: UPAR: A Kantian-Inspired Prompting Framework for Enhancing Large Language Model Capabilities
papers.authors: Hejia Geng,Boxun Xu,Peng Li
papers.summary: The UPAR prompting framework is proposed, designed to emulate the structure of human cognition within LLMs, enabling the extraction of structured information from complex contexts, prior planning of solutions, execution according to plan, and self-reflection and offering an epistemological foundation for existing prompting techniques.

papers.title: MathVista: Evaluating Mathematical Reasoning of Foundation Models in Visual Contexts
papers.authors: Pan Lu,Hritik Bansal,Tony Xia,Jiacheng Liu,Chunyuan Li,Hanna Hajishirzi,Hao Cheng,Kai-Wei Chang,Michel Galley,Jianfeng Gao
papers.summary: The benchmark MathVista is presented, a benchmark designed to amalgamate challenges from diverse mathematical and visual tasks and fuels future research in the development of general-purpose AI agents capable of tackling mathematically intensive and visually rich real-world tasks.

papers.title: SNIP: Bridging Mathematical Symbolic and Numeric Realms with Unified Pre-training
papers.authors: Kazem Meidani,Parshin Shojaee,Chandan K. Reddy,A. Farimani
papers.summary: SNIP, a Symbolic-Numeric Integrated Pre-training, is introduced, which employs joint contrastive learning between symbolic and numeric domains, enhancing their mutual similarities in the pre-trained embeddings, and provides cross-domain insights into the representations.

papers.title: FinMath: Injecting a Tree-structured Solver for Question Answering over Financial Reports
papers.venue: International Conference on Language Resources and Evaluation
papers.authors: Chenying Li,Wenbo Ye,Yilun Zhao
papers.summary: A new framework named FinMath is proposed, which improves the model’s numerical reasoning capacity by injecting a tree-structured neural model to perform multi-step numerical reasoning.

papers.title: GPT-NeoX-20B: An Open-Source Autoregressive Language Model
papers.authors: Sid Black,Stella Rose Biderman,Eric Hallahan,Quentin G. Anthony,Leo Gao,Laurence Golding,Horace He,Connor Leahy,Kyle McDonell,Jason Phang,M. Pieler,USVSN Sai Prashanth,Shivanshu Purohit,Laria Reynolds,J. Tow,Benqi Wang,Samuel Weinbach
papers.summary: GPT-NeoX-20B is introduced, a 20 billion parameter autoregressive language model trained on the Pile, whose weights will be made freely and openly available to the public through a permissive license.

papers.title: Exploring Length Generalization in Large Language Models
papers.authors: Cem Anil,Yuhuai Wu,Anders Andreassen,Aitor Lewkowycz,Vedant Misra,V. Ramasesh,Ambrose Slone,Guy Gur-Ari,Ethan Dyer,Behnam Neyshabur
papers.summary: This paper establishes that naively finetuning transformers on length generalization tasks shows significant generalization deficiencies independent of model scale, and shows that combining pretrained large language models' in-context learning abilities with scratchpad prompting results in a dramatic improvement in lengthgeneralization.

papers.title: Galactica: A Large Language Model for Science
papers.authors: Ross Taylor,Marcin Kardas,Guillem Cucurull,Thomas Scialom,A. Hartshorn,Elvis Saravia,Andrew Poulton,Viktor Kerkez,Robert Stojnic
papers.summary: Galactica is introduced: a large language model that can store, combine and reason about scientific knowledge, and sets a new state-of-the-art on downstream tasks such as PubMedQA and MedMCQA dev of 77.6% and 52.9%.

papers.title: Despite "super-human" performance, current LLMs are unsuited for decisions about ethics and safety
papers.authors: Joshua Albrecht,Ellie Kitanidis,Abraham J. Fetterman
papers.summary: This work provides a simple new prompting strategy that leads to yet another supposedly "super-human" result, this time outperforming humans at common sense ethical reasoning (as measured by accuracy on a subset of the ETHICS dataset).

papers.title: Mathematical Capabilities of ChatGPT
papers.authors: Simon Frieder,Luca Pinchetti,Ryan-Rhys Griffiths,Tommaso Salvatori,Thomas Lukasiewicz,Philipp Christian Petersen,Alexis Chevalier,J. Berner
papers.summary: It is found that ChatGPT can be used most successfully as a mathematical assistant for querying facts, acting as a Mathematical search engine and knowledge base interface, and GPT-4 can additionally be used for undergraduate-level mathematics but fails on graduate-level difficulty.

papers.title: Neural Graph Reasoning: Complex Logical Query Answering Meets Graph Databases
papers.authors: Hongyu Ren,Mikhail Galkin,M. Cochez,Zhaocheng Zhu,J. Leskovec
papers.summary: A holistic survey of CLQA is provided with a detailed taxonomy studying the field from multiple angles, including graph types (modality, reasoning domain, background semantics), modeling aspects, modeling aspects (encoder, processor, decoder), supported queries, datasets, evaluation metrics, and applications.

papers.title: ChatCoT: Tool-Augmented Chain-of-Thought Reasoning on Chat-based Large Language Models
papers.authors: Z. Chen,Kun Zhou,Beichen Zhang,Zheng Gong,Wayne Xin Zhao,Ji-rong Wen
papers.summary: This work proposes ChatCoT, a tool-augmented chain-of-thought reasoning framework for chat-based LLMs that can effectively leverage the multi-turn conversation ability of chat- based LLMs, and integrate the thought chain following and tools manipulation in a unified way.

papers.title: Deductive Verification of Chain-of-Thought Reasoning
papers.authors: Z. Ling,Yunhao Fang,Xuanlin Li,Zhiao Huang,Mingu Lee,R. Memisevic,Hao Su
papers.summary: This work proposes Natural Program, a natural language-based deductive reasoning format that enables models to generate precise reasoning steps where subsequent steps are more rigorously grounded on prior steps and significantly enhances the rigor and trustfulness of generated reasoning steps.

papers.title: Brain in a Vat: On Missing Pieces Towards Artificial General Intelligence in Large Language Models
papers.authors: Yuxi Ma,Chi Zhang,Song-Chun Zhu
papers.summary: This perspective paper comprehensively review existing evaluations of Large Language Models using both standardized tests and ability-oriented benchmarks to highlight the missing pieces in artificial general intelligence, that is, the unity of knowing and acting.

papers.title: Solving Challenging Math Word Problems Using GPT-4 Code Interpreter with Code-based Self-Verification
papers.authors: Aojun Zhou,Ke Wang,Zimu Lu,Weikang Shi,Sichun Luo,Zipeng Qin,Shaoqing Lu,Anya Jia,Linqi Song,Mingjie Zhan,Hongsheng Li
papers.summary: The effect of code on enhancing LLMs' reasoning capability by introducing different constraints on the Code Usage Frequency of GPT-4 Code Interpreter is explored, and a novel and effective prompting method, explicit \uline{c}ode-based \ULine{s}elf-\uline {v}erification~(CSV), is proposed to further boost the mathematical reasoning potential of GPN.

papers.title: No Train Still Gain. Unleash Mathematical Reasoning of Large Language Models with Monte Carlo Tree Search Guided by Energy Function
papers.authors: Haotian Xu
papers.summary: A method is proposed that incorporates Monte Carlo Tree Search (MCTS) and a lightweight energy function to rank decision steps and enable immediate reaction and precise reasoning in large language models without requiring additional fine-tuning or reinforcement learning with human feedback alignment.

papers.title: OWL: A Large Language Model for IT Operations
papers.authors: Hongcheng Guo,Jian Yang,Jiaheng Liu,Liqun Yang,Linzheng Chai,Jiaqi Bai,Junran Peng,Xiaorong Hu,Chao Chen,Dongfeng Zhang,Xu Shi,Tieqiao Zheng,Liangfan Zheng,Bo Zhang,Ke Xu,Zhoujun Li
papers.summary: The OWL is introduced, a large language model trained on the authors' collected OWL-Instruct dataset with a wide range of IT-related information, where the mixture-of-adapter strategy is proposed to improve the parameter-efficient tuning across different domains or tasks.

papers.title: MINT: Evaluating LLMs in Multi-turn Interaction with Tools and Language Feedback
papers.authors: Xingyao Wang,Zihan Wang,Jiateng Liu,Yangyi Chen,Lifan Yuan,Hao Peng,Heng Ji
papers.summary: MINT is introduced, a benchmark that evaluates LLMs' ability to solve tasks with multi-turn interactions by (1) using tools and (2) leveraging natural language feedback, and repurpose a diverse set of established evaluation datasets focusing on reasoning, coding, and decision-making into a compact subset for efficient evaluation.

papers.title: LPML: LLM-Prompting Markup Language for Mathematical Reasoning
papers.authors: Ryutaro Yamauchi,Sho Sonoda,Akiyoshi Sannai,Wataru Kumagai
papers.summary: This paper proposed a novel framework that integrates the Chain-of-Thought (CoT) method with an external tool (Python REPL) and discovered that by prompting LLMs to generate structured text in XML-like markup language, it could seamlessly integrate CoT and the external tool and control the undesired behaviors of LLMs.

papers.title: MetaMath: Bootstrap Your Own Mathematical Questions for Large Language Models
papers.authors: L. Yu,Weisen Jiang,Han Shi,Jincheng Yu,Zhengying Liu,Yu Zhang,James T. Kwok,Zheng Li,Adrian Weller,Weiyang Liu
papers.summary: Experimental results on two popular benchmarks for mathematical reasoning demonstrate that MetaMath outperforms a suite of open-source LLMs by a significant margin.

papers.title: NLPBench: Evaluating Large Language Models on Solving NLP Problems
papers.authors: Linxin Song,Jieyu Zhang,Lechao Cheng,Pengyuan Zhou,Tianyi Zhou,Irene Li
papers.summary: This study presents a unique benchmarking dataset, NLPBench, comprising 378 college-level NLP questions spanning various NLP topics sourced from Yale University's prior final exams, and reveals that the effectiveness of the advanced prompting strategies can be inconsistent, occasionally damaging LLM performance.

papers.title: CRAFT: Customizing LLMs by Creating and Retrieving from Specialized Toolsets
papers.authors: Lifan Yuan,Yangyi Chen,Xingyao Wang,Y. Fung,Hao Peng,Heng Ji
papers.summary: CRAFT is designed to be flexible and offers a plug-and-play approach to adapt off-the-shelf LLMs to unseen domains and modalities, without any finetuning, and achieves substantial improvements compared to strong baselines.

papers.title: Large Language Models as Analogical Reasoners
papers.authors: Michihiro Yasunaga,Xinyun Chen,Yujia Li,Panupong Pasupat,J. Leskovec,Percy Liang,Ed H. Chi,Denny Zhou
papers.summary: Inspired by analogical reasoning, a cognitive process in which humans draw from relevant past experiences to tackle new problems, this approach prompts language models to self-generate relevant exemplars or knowledge in the context, before proceeding to solve the given problem.

papers.title: Guiding Language Model Reasoning with Planning Tokens
papers.authors: Xinyi Wang,Lucas Caccia,O. Ostapenko,Xingdi Yuan,Alessandro Sordoni
papers.summary: 'planning tokens' are introduced at the start of each reasoning step, serving as a guide for the model, and these token embeddings are then fine-tuned along with the rest of the model parameters.

papers.title: Lemur: Harmonizing Natural Language and Code for Language Agents
papers.authors: Yiheng Xu,Hongjin Su,Chen Xing,Boyu Mi,Qian Liu,Weijia Shi,Binyuan Hui,Fan Zhou,Yitao Liu,Tianbao Xie,Zhoujun Cheng,Siheng Zhao,Lingpeng Kong,Bailin Wang,Caiming Xiong,Tao Yu
papers.summary: Lemur and Lemur-Chat are introduced, openly accessible language models optimized for both natural language and coding capabilities to serve as the backbone of versatile language agents, demonstrating balanced proficiencies in both domains, unlike existing open-source models that tend to specialize in either.

papers.title: Mathematical Word Problem Solution Evaluation via Data Preprocessing Approach
papers.authors: Andrii D. Nikolaiev,A. Anisimov
papers.summary: An overview of methods for processing mathematical text problems and correspondent domain datasets is described and a new approach to estimate MWP solutions is proposed that could use more context around the problem.

papers.title: : Leveraging Collective Human Intelligence to Study Large Language Models
papers.authors: Sebastin Santy,Ayana Bharadwaj,Sahith N. Dambekodi,Alex Albert,Cathy Yuan,Ranjay Krishna
papers.summary: L EET P ROMPT automatically evaluates human-LLM interactions to provide insights about both LLMs as well as human-interaction behavior, and finds that people use more diverse instruction strategies than these auto-* mechanisms.

papers.title: A Survey on Multi-hop Question Answering and Generation
papers.authors: Vaibhav Mavi,Anubhav Jangra,A. Jatowt
papers.summary: A general and formal definition of MHQA task is provided, the existing attempts to this highly interesting, yet quite challenging task are organized and summarized, and the best methods to createMHQA datasets are outlined.

papers.title: Why are NLP Models Fumbling at Elementary Math? A Survey of Deep Learning based Word Problem Solvers
papers.authors: S. S. Sundaram,Sairam Gurajada,M. Fisichella,Deepak P,Savitha Sam Abraham
papers.summary: This paper critically examine the various models that have been developed for solving word problems, their pros and cons and the challenges ahead, and endeavours to provide a road-map for future math word problem research.

papers.title: MMTM: Multi-Tasking Multi-Decoder Transformer for Math Word Problems
papers.authors: Keyur Faldu,Amit P. Sheth,Prashant Kikani,Darshan Patel
papers.summary: A novel model MMTM that leverages multi-tasking and multi-decoder during pre-training that achieves better mathematical reasoning ability and generalisability, which is demonstrated by outperforming the best state of the art baseline models from Seq2Seq, GTS, and Graph2Tree with a relative improvement on an adversarial challenge dataset SVAMP.

papers.title: Language models show human-like content effects on reasoning
papers.authors: I. Dasgupta,Andrew Kyle Lampinen,Stephanie C. Y. Chan,Antonia Creswell,D. Kumaran,James L. McClelland,Felix Hill
papers.summary: This work hypothesized that language models would show human-like content effects on abstract reasoning problems, and finds that state of the art large language models reflect many of the same patterns observed in humans across these tasks.

papers.title: Augmenting Operations Research with Auto-Formulation of Optimization Models from Problem Descriptions
papers.venue: Conference on Empirical Methods in Natural Language Processing
papers.authors: Rindranirina Ramamonjison,Haley Li,Timothy T. Yu,Shiqi He,Vishnu Rengan,Amin Banitalebi-Dehkordi,Zirui Zhou,Yong Zhang
papers.summary: An augmented intelligence system for simplifying and enhancing the modeling experience for operations research is described that receives a suggested formulation of an optimization problem based on its description and enables the users to validate and edit the suggestions.

papers.title: Mind's Eye: Grounded Language Model Reasoning through Simulation
papers.authors: Ruibo Liu,Jason Wei,S. Gu,Te-Yen Wu,Soroush Vosoughi,Claire Cui,Denny Zhou,Andrew M. Dai
papers.summary: Mind's Eye is presented, a paradigm to ground language model reasoning in the physical world by using a computational physics engine (DeepMind's MuJoCo) to simulate the possible outcomes, and then using the simulation results as part of the input, which enables language models to perform reasoning.

papers.title: Multi-View Reasoning: Consistent Contrastive Learning for Math Word Problem
papers.venue: Conference on Empirical Methods in Natural Language Processing
papers.authors: Wenqi Zhang,Yongliang Shen,Yanna Ma,Xiaoxia Cheng,Zeqi Tan,Qingpeng Nong,Weiming Lu
papers.summary: Experiments show the proposed multi-view consistent contrastive learning approach significantly outperforms the existing baselines, especially on complex problems, and can absorb the merits of both views and generate more diverse results consistent with the mathematical laws.

papers.title: Large Language Models Are Reasoning Teachers
papers.venue: Annual Meeting of the Association for Computational Linguistics
papers.authors: Namgyu Ho,Laura Schmid,Se-Young Yun
papers.summary: This paper uses very large models as reasoning teachers to enable complex reasoning in smaller models and reduce model size requirements by several orders of magnitude, and proposes Fine-tune-CoT, a method that generates reasoning samples from very large teacher models to fine-tunes smaller models.

papers.title: Batch Prompting: Efficient Inference with Large Language Model APIs
papers.authors: Zhoujun Cheng,Jungo Kasai,Tao Yu
papers.summary: Batch prompting, a simple alternative prompting approach that enables the LLM to run inference in batches, instead of one sample at a time, is proposed, which reduces both token and time costs while retaining downstream performance.

papers.title: Large Language Models Can Be Easily Distracted by Irrelevant Context
papers.authors: Freda Shi,Xinyun Chen,Kanishka Misra,Nathan Scales,David Dohan,E. Chi,Nathanael Scharli,Denny Zhou
papers.summary: This work investigates the distractibility of large language models, i.e., how the model problem-solving accuracy can be influenced by irrelevant context, and introduces Grade-School Math with Irrelevant Context (GSM-IC), an arithmetic reasoning dataset with irrelevant information in the problem description.

papers.title: Faithful Chain-of-Thought Reasoning
papers.authors: QING LYU,Shreya Havaldar,Adam Stein,Li Zhang,D. Rao,Eric Wong,Marianna Apidianaki,Chris Callison-Burch
papers.summary: Faithful CoT, a reasoning framework involving two stages: Translation and Problem Solving (reasoning chain $\rightarrow$ answer), using an LM and a deterministic solver respectively, guarantees that the reasoning chain provides a faithful explanation of the final answer.

papers.title: Synthetic Prompting: Generating Chain-of-Thought Demonstrations for Large Language Models
papers.authors: Zhihong Shao,Yeyun Gong,Yelong Shen,Minlie Huang,Nan Duan,Weizhu Chen
papers.summary: Synthetic prompting is introduced, a method that leverages a few handcrafted examples to prompt the model to generate more examples by itself, and selects effective demonstrations to elicit better reasoning.

papers.title: A Categorical Archive of ChatGPT Failures
papers.authors: A. Borji

papers.title: Techniques to Improve Neural Math Word Problem Solvers
papers.authors: Youyuan Zhang
papers.summary: A new encoder-decoder architecture that fully leverages the question text and preserves step-wise commutative law is proposed and outperforms state-of-the-art neural MWP solvers, showing the effectiveness of the techniques.

papers.title: Is ChatGPT a General-Purpose Natural Language Processing Task Solver?
papers.authors: Chengwei Qin,Aston Zhang,Zhuosheng Zhang,Jiaao Chen,Michihiro Yasunaga,Diyi Yang
papers.summary: It is found that ChatGPT performs well on many tasks favoring reasoning capabilities while it still faces challenges when solving specific tasks such as sequence tagging, and with extensive empirical studies, both the effectiveness and limitations of the current version of ChatG PT are demonstrated.

papers.title: A Multi-Modal Neural Geometric Solver with Textual Clauses Parsed from Diagram
papers.venue: International Joint Conference on Artificial Intelligence
papers.authors: Ming-Liang Zhang,Fei Yin,Cheng-Lin Liu
papers.summary: This work converts diagrams into basic textual clauses to describe diagram features effectively, and proposes a new neural solver called PGPSNet to fuse multi-modal information efficiently and promote geometric understanding and reasoning.

papers.title: ART: Automatic multi-step reasoning and tool-use for large language models
papers.authors: Bhargavi Paranjape,Scott M. Lundberg,Sameer Singh,Hanna Hajishirzi,Luke Zettlemoyer,Marco Tulio Ribeiro
papers.summary: Automatic Reasoning and Tool-use (ART), a framework that uses frozen LLMs to automatically generate intermediate reasoning steps as a program, achieves a substantial improvement over few-shot prompting and automatic CoT on unseen tasks in the BigBench and MMLU benchmarks, and matches performance of hand-crafted CoT prompts on a majority of these tasks.

papers.title: Retrieving Multimodal Information for Augmented Generation: A Survey
papers.authors: Ruochen Zhao,Hailin Chen,Weishi Wang,Fangkai Jiao,Xuan Long Do,Chengwei Qin,Bosheng Ding,Xiaobao Guo,Minzhi Li,Xingxuan Li,Shafiq R. Joty
papers.summary: This survey reviews methods that assist and augment generative models by retrieving multimodal knowledge, whose formats range from images, codes, tables, graphs, to audio, and offers a promising solution to important concerns such as factuality, reasoning, interpretability, and robustness.

papers.title: A Survey of Large Language Models
papers.authors: Wayne Xin Zhao,Kun Zhou,Junyi Li,Tianyi Tang,Xiaolei Wang,Yupeng Hou,Yingqian Min,Beichen Zhang,Junjie Zhang,Zican Dong,Yifan Du,Chen Yang,Yushuo Chen,Z. Chen,Jinhao Jiang,Ruiyang Ren,Yifan Li,Xinyu Tang,Zikang Liu,Peiyu Liu,J. Nie,Ji-rong Wen
papers.summary: A review of the recent advances of large language models by introducing the background, key findings, and mainstream techniques, and focusing on four major aspects of LLMs, namely pre-training, adaptation tuning, utilization, and capacity evaluation.

papers.title: Boosted Prompt Ensembles for Large Language Models
papers.authors: Silviu Pitis,Michael Ruogu Zhang,Andrew Wang,Jimmy Ba
papers.summary: A prompt ensembling method for large language models, which uses a small dataset to construct a set of few shot prompts that together comprise a ``boosted prompt ensemble'' that outperforms single-prompt output-space ensembles and bagged prompt-spaceEnsemble on the GSM8k and AQuA datasets, among others.

papers.title: Decomposition Enhances Reasoning via Self-Evaluation Guided Decoding
papers.authors: Yuxi Xie,Kenji Kawaguchi,Yiran Zhao,Xu Zhao,MingSung Kan,Junxian He,Qizhe Xie
papers.summary: An effective prompting approach that integrates self-evaluation guidance through stochastic beam search is proposed that explores the reasoning search space using a well-calibrated automatic criterion and enables an efficient search to produce higher-quality final predictions.

papers.title: CRITIC: Large Language Models Can Self-Correct with Tool-Interactive Critiquing
papers.authors: Zhibin Gou,Zhihong Shao,Yeyun Gong,Yelong Shen,Yujiu Yang,Nan Duan,Weizhu Chen
papers.summary: A framework called CRITIC is introduced that allows LLMs, which are essentially"black boxes" to validate and progressively amend their own outputs in a manner similar to human interaction with tools.

papers.title: RCOT: Detecting and Rectifying Factual Inconsistency in Reasoning by Reversing Chain-of-Thought
papers.authors: Tianci Xue,Ziqi Wang,Zhenhailong Wang,Chi Han,Pengfei Yu,Heng Ji
papers.summary: This work proposes RCoT (Reversing Chain-of-Thought), a novel method to improve LLMs' reasoning abilities by automatically detecting and rectifying factual inconsistency in LLMs, generated solutions and finds that manually written fine-grained feedback can dramatically improve LLM's reasoning abilities.

papers.title: A Symbolic Framework for Systematic Evaluation of Mathematical Reasoning with Transformers
papers.authors: Jordan Meadows,Marco Valentino,Damien Teney,André Freitas
papers.summary: A data generation method for producing intricate mathematical derivations, and systematically perturb them with respect to syntax, structure, and semantics, employing symbolic algebra for scalable data production and augmentation.

papers.title: Let GPT be a Math Tutor: Teaching Math Word Problem Solvers with Customized Exercise Generation
papers.authors: Zhenwen Liang,W. Yu,Tanmay Rajpurohit,Peter Clark,Xiangliang Zhang,Ashwin Kaylan
papers.summary: A novel approach for distilling math word problem solving capabilities from large language models (LLMs) into smaller, more efficient student models designed to consider the student model's weaknesses and foster a tailored learning experience by generating targeted exercises aligned with educational science principles.

papers.title: Automatic Model Selection with Large Language Models for Reasoning
papers.authors: Xu Zhao,Yuxi Xie,Kenji Kawaguchi,Junxian He,Qizhe Xie
papers.summary: This work demonstrates that it is possible to combine the best of both worlds by using different models for different problems, employing a large language model (LLM) to perform model selection.

papers.title: Mixture of Prompt Experts for Generalizable and Interpretable Question Answering
papers.authors: Chenglei Si,Weijia Shi,Chen Zhao,Luke Zettlemoyer,Jordan L. Boyd-Graber
papers.summary: A Mixture-of-Prompt-Experts (MOPE) system that ensembles multiple specialized LLMs that significantly outperforms any single specialized model on a collection of 12 QA datasets from four reasoning types.

papers.title: Code Prompting: a Neural Symbolic Method for Complex Reasoning in Large Language Models
papers.authors: Y. Hu,Haotong Yang,Zhouchen Lin,Muhan Zhang
papers.summary: This work explores code prompting, a neural symbolic prompting method with both zero-shot and few-shot versions which triggers code as intermediate steps, and performs extensive ablation studies and error analyses and identifies several exclusive advantages of using symbolic promptings compared to natural language.

papers.title: Boosting Language Models Reasoning with Chain-of-Knowledge Prompting
papers.authors: J. Wang,Qiushi Sun,Nuo Chen,Xiang Lorraine Li,Ming Gao
papers.summary: This work proposes a novel Chain-of-Knowledge prompting, where it aims at eliciting LLMs to generate explicit pieces of knowledge evidence in the form of structure triple, and introduces a F^2-Verification method to estimate the reliability of the reasoning chains in terms of factuality and faithfulness.

papers.title: Math Word Problem Solving by Generating Linguistic Variants of Problem Statements
papers.venue: Proceedings of the 61st Annual Meeting of the Association for Computational Linguistics (Volume 4: Student Research Workshop)
papers.authors: Syed Rifat Raiyan,Md. Nafis Faiyaz,S. Kabir,Mohsinul Kabir,H. Mahmud,Md. Kamrul Hasan
papers.summary: This paper proposes a framework for MWP solvers based on the generation of linguistic variants of the problem text and shows that training on linguistic variant of problem statements and voting on candidate predictions improve the mathematical reasoning and robustness of the model.

papers.title: A Comprehensive Overview of Large Language Models
papers.authors: Humza Naveed,Asad Ullah Khan,Shi Qiu,Muhammad Saqib,Saeed Anwar,Muhammad Usman,N. Barnes,A. Mian
papers.summary: This review article is intended to provide a systematic survey, but also a quick comprehensive reference for the researchers and practitioners to draw insights from extensive informative summaries of the existing works to advance the LLM research direction.

papers.title: ARB: Advanced Reasoning Benchmark for Large Language Models
papers.authors: Tomohiro Sawada,Daniel Paleka,Alex Havrilla,Pranav Tadepalli,Paula Vidas,Alexander Kranias,John J. Nay,Kshitij Gupta,Aran Komatsuzaki
papers.summary: This work introduces ARB, a novel benchmark composed of advanced reasoning problems in multiple fields, featuring problems in mathematics, physics, biology, chemistry, and law, and introduces a rubric-based evaluation approach, allowing GPT-4 to score its own intermediate reasoning steps.

papers.title: Guiding Mathematical Reasoning via Mastering Commonsense Formula Knowledge
papers.authors: Jia-Yin Liu,Zhenya Huang,Zhiyuan Ma,Qi Liu,Enhong Chen,Tianhuang Su,Haifeng Liu
papers.summary: A novel Formula-mastered Solver (FOMAS) is established with two systems drawing insight from the dual process theory, including a Knowledge System and a Reasoning System, to learn and apply formula knowledge, respectively to improve both reasoning accuracy and interpretability.

papers.title: MathAttack: Attacking Large Language Models Towards Math Solving Ability
papers.authors: Zihao Zhou,Qiufeng Wang,Mingyu Jin,Jie Yao,Jianan Ye,Wei Liu,Wei Wang,Xiaowei Huang,Kaizhu Huang
papers.summary: This work proposes a MathAttack model to attack MWP samples which are closer to the essence of security in solving math problems, and proposes a new dataset RobustMath to evaluate the robustness of LLMs in math solving ability.

papers.title: Contrastive Decoding Improves Reasoning in Large Language Models
papers.authors: Sean O'Brien,Mike Lewis
papers.summary: Overall, Contrastive Decoding outperforms nucleus sampling for long-form generation and greedy decoding for reasoning tasks, making it a powerful general purpose method for generating text from language models.

papers.title: Promptbreeder: Self-Referential Self-Improvement Via Prompt Evolution
papers.authors: Chrisantha Fernando,D. Banarse,Henryk Michalewski,Simon Osindero,Tim Rocktaschel
papers.summary: Promptbreeder is a general-purpose self-referential self-improvement mechanism that evolves and adapts prompts for a given domain and outperforms state-of-the-art prompt strategies such as Chain- of-Thought and Plan-and-Solve Prompting on commonly used arithmetic and commonsense reasoning benchmarks.

papers.title: L2CEval: Evaluating Language-to-Code Generation Capabilities of Large Language Models
papers.authors: Ansong Ni,Pengcheng Yin,Yilun Zhao,Martin Riddell,Troy Feng,Rui Shen,Stephen Yin,Ye Liu,Semih Yavuz,Caiming Xiong,Shafiq R. Joty,Yingbo Zhou,Dragomir R. Radev,Arman Cohan
papers.summary: This work presents L2CEval, a systematic evaluation of the language-to-code generation capabilities of LLMs on 7 tasks across the domain spectrum of semantic parsing, math reasoning and Python programming, analyzing the factors that potentially affect their performance.

papers.title: Corex: Pushing the Boundaries of Complex Reasoning through Multi-Model Collaboration
papers.authors: Qiushi Sun,Zhangyue Yin,Xiang Li,Zhiyong Wu,Xipeng Qiu,Lingpeng Kong
papers.summary: This paper introduces Corex, a suite of novel general-purpose strategies that transform LLMs into autonomous agents pioneering multi-model collaborations for complex task-solving, and demonstrates the cost-effectiveness of the method, facilitating collaboration among different LLMs and promoting annotation efficiency.

papers.title: Fill in the Blank: Exploring and Enhancing LLM Capabilities for Backward Reasoning in Math Word Problems
papers.authors: Aniruddha Deb,Neeva Oza,Sarthak Singla,Dinesh Khandelwal,Dinesh Garg,Parag Singla
papers.summary: This paper formally defines the backward reasoning task on math word problems and modify three datasets to evaluate this task: GSM8k, SVAMP and MultiArith, and proposes three novel techniques that improve performance.

papers.title: One Clinician Is All You Need–Cardiac Magnetic Resonance Imaging Measurement Extraction: Deep Learning Algorithm Development
papers.authors: Pulkit Singh,Julian S Haimovich,C. Reeder,S. Khurshid,S. Emily,Lau,Jonathan W Cunningham,A. Philippakis,C. D. Anderson,J. Ho,S. Lubitz,P. Batra
papers.summary: This study demonstrated that a domain-agnostic pretrained transformer model is able to effectively extract quantitative clinical measurements from diagnostic reports with a relatively small number of gold-standard annotations.

papers.title: Applying Structural and Dense Semantic Matching for the ARQMath Lab 2022, CLEF
papers.venue: Conference and Labs of the Evaluation Forum
papers.authors: Wei Zhong,Yuqing Xie,Jimmy J. Lin
papers.summary: This work describes the participation of the team in the ARQMath 2022 Lab, where two highly complementary methods for effective math answer and formula retrieval are applied, using a lexical sparse retriever and a fine-tuned bi-encoder dense retriever to capture contextual similarity and semantic matching.

papers.title: JRIRD at the NTCIR-16 FinNum-3 Task: Investigating the Effect of Numerical Representations in Manager’s Claim Detection
papers.authors: Shunsuke Onuma,Kazuma Kadowaki

papers.title: Innovations in Neural Data-to-text Generation
papers.authors: Mandar Sharma,Ajay K. Gogineni,Naren Ramakrishnan
papers.summary: This survey draws boundaries separating DTG from the rest of the natural language generation (NLG) landscape, encompassing an up-to-date synthesis of the literature, and highlighting the stages of technological adoption from within and outside the greater NLG umbrella.

papers.title: mGPT: Few-Shot Learners Go Multilingual
papers.authors: Oleh Shliazhko,Alena Fenogenova,M. Tikhonova,V. Mikhailov,A. Kozlova,Tatiana Shavrina
papers.summary: Two autoregressive GPT-like models with 1.3 billion and 13 billion parameters trained on 60 languages from 25 language families using Wikipedia and Colossal Clean Crawled Corpus are introduced and compared with the state-of-the-art multilingual model XGLM.

papers.title: Development of a Neural Network-Based Mathematical Operation Protocol for Embedded Hexadecimal Digits Using Neural Architecture Search (NAS)
papers.authors: Victor Robila,Kexin Pei,Junfeng Yang
papers.summary: A comparison between human-developed machine learning model and models sampled through Neural Architecture Search (NAS) determine an efficient approach to solve the problem of addition using embedded hexadecimal digits.

papers.title: How does GPT-2 compute greater-than?: Interpreting mathematical abilities in a pre-trained language model
papers.authors: Michael Hanna,Ollie Liu,Alexandre Variengien
papers.summary: The basic mathematical abilities often acquired by pre-trained language models are investigated, and mechanistic interpretability techniques are used to explain the (limited) mathematical abilities of GPT-2 small.

papers.title: MultiTabQA: Generating Tabular Answers for Multi-Table Question Answering
papers.venue: Annual Meeting of the Association for Computational Linguistics
papers.authors: Vaishali Pal,Andrew Yates,E. Kanoulas,M. de Rijke
papers.summary: This model, MultiTabQA, not only answers questions over multiple tables, but also generalizes to generate tabular answers, which outperforms state-of-the-art single table QA models adapted to a multi-table QA setting by finetuning on three datasets: Spider, Atis and GeoQuery.

papers.title: The Value of Numbers in Clinical Text Classification
papers.authors: Kristian Miok,P. Corcoran,Irena Spasic
papers.summary: The results showed that even a handful of numerical features can significantly improve text classification performance, and it was concluded that commonly used document representations do not represent numbers in a way that machine learning algorithms can effectively utilize them as features.

papers.title: Arithmetic with Language Models: from Memorization to Computation
papers.authors: D. Maltoni,M. Ferrara
papers.summary: These findings support the hypotheses that the language model works as an Encoding-Regression-Decoding machine where the computation takes place in the value space once the input token representation is mapped to an appropriate internal representation.

papers.title: On the Paradox of Learning to Reason from Data
papers.venue: International Joint Conference on Artificial Intelligence
papers.authors: Honghua Zhang,Liunian Harold Li,Tao Meng,Kai-Wei Chang,Guy Van den Broeck
papers.summary: This study provides an explanation for this paradox: instead of learning to emulate the correct reasoning function, BERT has, in fact, learned statistical features that inherently exist in logical reasoning problems.

papers.title: When to Make Exceptions: Exploring Language Models as Accounts of Human Moral Judgment
papers.authors: Zhijing Jin,Sydney Levine,Fernando Gonzalez,Ojasv Kamal,Maarten Sap,Mrinmaya Sachan,Rada Mihalcea,J. Tenenbaum,B. Scholkopf
papers.summary: A novel moral chain of thought (MORALCOT) prompting strategy that combines the strengths of LLMs with theories of moral reasoning developed in cognitive science to predict human moral judgments, suggesting that modeling human reasoning might be necessary to capture the flexibility of the human moral mind.

papers.title: Self-planning Code Generation with Large Language Model
papers.authors: Xue Jiang,Yihong Dong,Lecheng Wang,Qiwei Shang,Ge Li
papers.summary: This paper proposes a self-planning code generation method with large language model, which consists of two phases, namely planning phase and implementation phase, which demonstrates a marked superiority over naive direct generation approaches with language model.

papers.title: REFINER: Reasoning Feedback on Intermediate Representations
papers.authors: Debjit Paul,Mete Ismayilzada,Maxime Peyrard,Beatriz Borges,Antoine Bosselut,Robert West,B. Faltings
papers.summary: REFINER is a framework for finetuning LMs to explicitly generate intermediate reasoning steps while interacting with a critic model that provides automated feedback on the reasoning that provides structured feedback that the reasoning uses to iteratively improve its intermediate arguments.

papers.title: Large Language Models Are Not Abstract Reasoners
papers.authors: Gaël Gendron,Qiming Bao,M. Witbrock,G. Dobbie
papers.summary: This paper performs extensive evaluations of state-of-the-art LLMs on abstract reasoning tasks, showing that they achieve very limited performance in contrast with other natural language tasks, and investigates the reasons for this difference.

papers.title: KwaiYiiMath: Technical Report
papers.authors: Jia-Yi Fu,Lei Lin,Xiaoyang Gao,Pengli Liu,Zhengzong Chen,Zhirui Yang,Shengnan Zhang,Xue Zheng,Yan Li,Yuliang Liu,Xucheng Ye,Yiqiao Liao,Chao Liao,Bin Chen,Chengru Song,Junchen Wan,Zijia Lin,Fuzheng Zhang,Zhongyuan Wang,Di Zhang,Kun Gai
papers.summary: The KwaiyiiMath is introduced, which enhances the mathematical reasoning abilities of KwaiYiiBase1, by applying Supervised Fine-Tuning (SFT) and Reinforced Learning from Human Feedback (RLHF), including on both English and Chinese mathematical tasks.

papers.title: LIFT: Language-Interfaced Fine-Tuning for Non-Language Machine Learning Tasks
papers.authors: Tuan Dinh,Yuchen Zeng,Ruisu Zhang,Ziqian Lin,Shashank Rajput,Michael Gira,Jy-yong Sohn,Dimitris Papailiopoulos,Kangwook Lee
papers.summary: Language-Interfaced Fine-Tuning is proposed and found that LIFT performs comparably well across a wide range of low-dimensional classification and regression tasks, matching the performances of the best baselines in many cases, especially for the classification tasks.

papers.title: Transformers Learn Shortcuts to Automata
papers.authors: Bingbin Liu,J. Ash,Surbhi Goel,A. Krishnamurthy,Cyril Zhang
